docs.lead_paragraph: When Jeffrey A. Craig was a high school student with acne in the early 1980's, his parents took him to see Michael Ben Klein, a dermatologist, for treatment. Over the next two decades, the young patient and his former physician became friends, boating and barbecuing and dabbling in a real estate deal or two together. When Dr. Klein's medical license was revoked in December 1997, because the State Department of Health found, among other things, that he had sexually harassed his patients and staff, used narcotics, carried a gun in his office and sat under his desk, it was Mr. Craig who testified on his behalf at an investigative hearing.

headline.main: Ex-Doctor Is Held in Arson As Troubled Life Unravels

docs.abstract: Article discusses troubled life of Michael Ben Klein, former dermatologist who is charged with throwing firebomb through window of building owned by Jeffrey A Craig in Huntington, NY (M)
docs.snippet: When Jeffrey A. Craig was a high school student with acne in the early 1980's, his parents took him to see Michael Ben Klein, a dermatologist, for treatment. Over the next two decades, the young patient and his former physician became friends,...

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK HUNTINGTON: POWER PLANT PLAN CRITICIZED Some residents and a town councilman are criticizing a plan by Kings Park Energy to build a 300-megawatt power plant on the Huntington-Smithtown border. Residents say that there are two power plants nearby and that they do not want a third. Mark Cuthbertson, a Huntington councilman, accused the State Public Service Commission yesterday of failing to publicize a meeting of the commission and Kings Park Energy last night. David C. Flanagan, a spokesman for the commission, said the meeting had been publicized. Hope Reeves (NYT) ALTAMONT: FARMLAND PROTECTION The state will provide more than $12 million to protect farmland from development in 11 counties. The money will not only keep the land in agricultural production, it will also preserve the rural character of the surrounding areas, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday during an appearance at a farmers' market here. The latest grants bring to more than $40 million the money put toward protection of farmland since 1996. Parcels must be kept in active agricultural production and in areas facing development pressures to qualify for the program. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: A crucial measure of consumer confidence rebounded sharply in March after falling for five consecutive months. Financial markets interpreted the data, which were much better than anticipated, optimistically. Stock prices jumped after the figures were released at 10 a.m. By the close, all three major market indexes had risen by more than 2.5 percent. [Page C13.]

headline.main: March Survey Of Consumers Is Brighter

docs.abstract: Stock rise sharply after Conference Board reports that its consumer confidence index rose to 117.0 in March from 109.2 in February, first increase since September; economists are reluctant to read much into one monthly figure, but say recent decline in consumer confidence may be bottoming out; graphs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Special-interest groups poured more than $66.3 million into efforts to influence state legislation last year, and the biggest spenders were connected to the health care industry, according to a yearly report released today by the state lobbying commission. Lobbyists and their clients spent $5.6 million less in 2000 than in the previous year, when a coalition of health care workers and hospitals poured $10 million into an advertising campaign to win passage of an insurance program for the poor.

headline.main: Health Care Lobby Leads List Of the Big Spenders in Albany

docs.abstract: New York State Lobbying Commission reports that special-interest groups poured more than $66.3 million into efforts to influence state legislation last year, and biggest spenders were connected to health care industry (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as lawmakers here wrestle with accusations that Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's nominee for state treasurer, Isabel Miranda, was fired from a job at Citibank and accused of misusing an expense account for personal trips, Ms. Miranda's continued ties to her most recent employer have become the subject of growing scrutiny. When she was named acting treasurer last week, Ms. Miranda took an unpaid leave of absence from U.S. Trust Company of New Jersey. U.S. Trust, a subsidiary of the Charles Schwab Corporation, is one of the nation's largest trustees for bonds issued by government agencies.

headline.main: New Questions On Nominee For Treasurer

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Rival Foreign Policy Camps Compete for Bush's Ear Two competing foreign policy camps are emerging in the Bush administration -- an ideologically conservative Pentagon and a more moderate State Department -- and they have already provided President Bush with conflicting advice on issues like relations with North Korea and the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein. docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Salazar, a machine repairman at the Chrysler engine factory here, has made one sacrifice as overtime has disappeared and layoffs have begun: he has postponed the purchase of a Dodge Ram pickup to replace his bright red Dodge Durango. But hold the pity. That Durango is just two years old, and his 20-foot powerboat is ready on Lake Michigan. ''If I got laid off,'' he shrugged, ''I'd go fishing.''

headline.main: Contract Gains Ease Sting of Layoffs for Auto Workers

docs.abstract: Hard economic times are proving far less harsh on workers in auto factories than in other industries; while other unions struggled in 1990's, United Automobile Workers used its strength to win long list of benefits; workers laid off at Chrysler Corp draw roughly two-thirds of straight-time pay for 42 weeks, through mix of state and company payments; they then resume drawing full pay, nearly $50,000 per year, until end of current contract, in September 2003; they also stay in one of nation's best private health plans; Chrysler is insulated from cost of its unemployment benefits because its labor contracts have forced it to set aside money for last decade; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A slowing economy and renewed double-digit inflation in health insurance costs are all but certain to cause an increase in the uninsured later this year and next, in the view of experts from foundations, business and consumer groups and the insurance industry. And while the issue is not now a major priority for the Bush administration or either party on Capitol Hill, Congress is beginning to consider tentative steps toward expanding coverage.

headline.main: Congress Begins Planning for Increased Number of Uninsured as Economy Slows

docs.abstract: Congress begins to weigh tentative steps toward expanding health coverge amid warnings from health experts that slowing economy and renewed double-digit inflation in health insurance costs are all but certain to cause an increase in uninsured later in 2001; Republicans and few Democrats are proposing tax credits to help people buy insurance; Democrats and few Republicans are seeking to expand participation in existing federally aided programs; number of uninsured totaled 42.5 million, or 14.2 percent of population, in 1999; graph (M)

byline.original: By ADAM CLYMER and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: One doctor performed an unneeded hysterectomy on an ailing patient without giving her a routine checkup; she had a problem with her lungs. New York State proclaimed another doctor an imminent danger after he botched baby deliveries. A third doctor cleared patients for surgery without examining them. These doctors have three things in common: all practiced medicine at a New York City hospital; all were disciplined by the state for negligence; and then all easily found work again. Two of them are still treating patients today.

headline.main: MEDICAL RETREADS: A special report.; Doctors Punished by State But Prized at the Hospitals

docs.abstract: Special report, Medical Retreads, focuses on ease with which doctors, disciplined for negligence by New York State, find work at other hospitals or are retained by hospital where problems occurred; neither state nor federal government lays out how hospitals should handle such doctors, nor does national organization that accredits hospitals; many New York hospitals routinely hire and retain doctors with bad records, especially those who bring in lot of money; hospital administrators, often doctors themselves, argue that almost every doctor who errs deserves second chance, or even third, and many receive them, sometimes moving from hospital to hospital between punishments for negligence or incompetent care; state data indicate more than three-fourths of doctors disciplined over last eight years resumed working almost immediately after state punished them, and that 285 who were disciplined kept medical licenses from 1992 until 1999; State Health Department officials, criticized for failing to revoke medical licenses, say complicated disciplinary system makes it hard to do so; argue that hospitals share responsibility to weed out bad doctors, but that they lack specific rules on hiring and monitoring doctors punished by state; health care policy experts say hospitals are hardly pressed to make do with troubled doctors in New York City, where ratio of doctors to population is 50 percent higher than national average; state data show, however, that doctors with disciplinary problems are often among top third of moneymakers at their hospitals; charts; photos (L)

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and FORD FESSENDEN

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The state medical associations of California, Georgia and Texas joined individual doctors from seven states yesterday in a federal lawsuit that accused eight health insurers, including Aetna Inc. and the Cigna Corporation, of engaging in ''a pattern of racketeering activity'' to deny necessary medical care. The state organizations, which represent more than 75,000 doctors, contend that the insurers had used ''cost-based criteria to approve or deny claims'' for payment and had offered cash incentives to claim reviewers who would deny or limit tests and treatments that doctors felt were necessary.

headline.main: State Groups Join Doctors in Suing Insurers
